articles.headline: Job Losses and Oil Surge Spread Economic Gloom
articles.snippet: Hopes that the U.S. might skirt a recession sank in the face of indications that the economy is gripped by a slowdown and pressured by record fuel prices.
articles.abstract: Hopes that the U.S. might skirt a recession sank in the face of indications that the economy is gripped by a slowdown and pressured by record fuel prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate surged to 5.5 percent in May from 5 percent  the sharpest monthly spike in 22 years  as the economy lost 49,000 jobs, registering a fifth consecutive month of decline, the Labor Department reported Friday.

articles.headline: Holdouts Test Aid’s Limitations as FEMA Shuts a Trailer Park
articles.snippet: Trailer park closings are testing oft-repeated promises on rectifying the social ills that Hurricane Katrina exposed.
articles.abstract: Trailer park closings are testing oft-repeated promises on rectifying the social ills that Hurricane Katrina exposed.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAKER, La.  Theresa August spent the official closing day of the Renaissance Village trailer park singing, muttering to herself and dancing on a picnic table. Finally, wearing an infant’s flowered onesie on her head like a kerchief, she began to pack up.

articles.headline: Serving Time, but Lacking Remorse
articles.snippet: Plenty of criminals head to prison still believing they’re above the law, but William S. Lerach, once a feared plaintiffs’ lawyer, takes the cake.
articles.abstract: Plenty of criminals head to prison still believing they’re above the law, but William S. Lerach, once a feared plaintiffs’ lawyer, takes the cake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some guys just don’t know when to shut up. William S. Lerach is one of those guys.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Take a Nerve-Rattling Jump Past $138
articles.snippet: Friday’s jump capped a second day of strong gains on energy markets, and fed suspicions that commodities might be caught in an investment bubble.
articles.abstract: Friday’s jump capped a second day of strong gains on energy markets, and fed suspicions that commodities might be caught in an investment bubble.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rise in oil prices turned into a stampede on Friday with futures jumping a staggering $11 a barrel to set a record above $138 a barrel. The unprecedented surge came as the dollar fell sharply against the euro and a senior Israeli politician once again raised the possibility of an attack against Iran.

articles.headline: Candidates Forgo Soft Money, but Conventions Rake It In
articles.snippet: Fund-raising for national party conventions could test the commitment of Barack Obama and John McCain to erase the influence of big money.
articles.abstract: Fund-raising for national party conventions could test the commitment of Barack Obama and John McCain to erase the influence of big money.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Senator Barack Obama’s first acts after claiming the Democratic nomination was declaring he would not take special-interest money for his presidential bid, even going so far as to bar lobbyists from donating to the Democratic National Committee.

articles.headline: In Turnabout, Antitrust Unit Looks at Intel
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission’s decision to look into accusations about Intel’s pricing reversed a previous stance that had blocked the inquiry for many months.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission’s decision to look into accusations about Intel’s pricing reversed a previous stance that had blocked the inquiry for many months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A global legal battle between the two largest makers of computer processors took an abrupt turn this week when the Federal Trade Commission opened a formal antitrust investigation of the Intel Corporation.

articles.headline: In Shift for Japan, Salarymen Blow the Whistle
articles.snippet: A decade ago, corporate whistle-blowing was almost unheard of in Japan. But a broad transformation of Japan and the global economy has occurred.
articles.abstract: A decade ago, corporate whistle-blowing was almost unheard of in Japan. But a broad transformation of Japan and the global economy has occurred.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  A car company that hid dangerous flaws to avoid embarrassing recalls. A meat processor that sold ground pig hearts as beef. A fancy restaurant chain that served customers leftover sashimi from other diners.

articles.headline: Tax Laws Popularize the Small Foundation
articles.snippet: The number of smaller foundations and other charities has increased 49 percent from 1995 to 2005.
articles.abstract: The number of smaller foundations and other charities has increased 49 percent from 1995 to 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John Lane III assumed the investment responsibilities for the Edward H. Lane Foundation in 2004, he took on a lot of headaches.

articles.headline: The Card-Carrying Starbucks Fan
articles.snippet: Starbucks’s new rewards program demonstrates just how hard it is, in any industry, to build a program that inspires allegiance to a particular brand.
articles.abstract: Starbucks’s new rewards program demonstrates just how hard it is, in any industry, to build a program that inspires allegiance to a particular brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 1981, when American Airlines was struggling to differentiate itself in a newly deregulated industry, it invented the frequent flier mile. Ten years later, American Express responded to its own competitive crisis by introducing what we now know as Membership Rewards.

articles.headline: As Ills Persist, Afghan Leader Is Losing Luster
articles.snippet: Concern is growing that Hamid Karzai, long a darling of the U.S., is not up to addressing his country’s troubles.
articles.abstract: Concern is growing that Hamid Karzai, long a darling of the U.S., is not up to addressing his country’s troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After six years in which Hamid Karzai has been the darling of the United States and its allies, his luster may be fading.

articles.headline: Bank of America Is Firm on Countrywide Buyout
articles.snippet: Even as Countrywide Financial’s ugly financial results show no signs of abating, Bank of America says it is committed to go through with its takeover plans.
articles.abstract: Even as Countrywide Financial’s ugly financial results show no signs of abating, Bank of America says it is committed to go through with its takeover plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN the six months since Bank of America announced its plans to take over Countrywide Financial, many investors have doubted that the $4 billion deal for the hobbled mortgage lender would get done. Bank of America has been strangely silent about its plans for merging the two operations, with the exception of a cryptic regulatory filing last month warning that investors should not count on it assuming all of Countrywide’s debt.

articles.headline: Pay It Back if You Didn’t Earn It
articles.snippet: Clawback provisions, which allow companies to recover executive pay that they find to have been based on incorrect financial statements, have become more popular.
articles.abstract: Clawback provisions, which allow companies to recover executive pay that they find to have been based on incorrect financial statements, have become more popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: READY for some good news from your humble research assistant? During this proxy season, almost 300 companies adopted provisions allowing them to recover executive pay that they find to have been based on incorrect financial statements. Four years ago, such clawback policies were found at only 14 companies.

articles.headline: Clinton Ends Campaign With Clear Call to Elect Obama
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made an emotional and unequivocal appeal for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton made an emotional and unequivocal appeal for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton brought her campaign for the White House to an end on Saturday with a rousing farewell to thousands of supporters here and an emotional and unequivocal call for her voters to get behind Senator Barack Obama, the man who defeated her for the Democratic nomination.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Mark Leibovich

articles.headline: Oil Prices Raise Cost of Making Range of Goods
articles.snippet: Companies that make goods using raw materials derived from oil face unpleasant choices as their costs skyrocket.
articles.abstract: Companies that make goods using raw materials derived from oil face unpleasant choices as their costs skyrocket.
articles.lead_paragraph: Surging oil prices are beginning to cut into the profits of a wide range of American businesses, pushing many to raise prices and maneuver aggressively to offset the rising cost of merchandise made from petroleum.

articles.headline: Researchers Fail to Reveal Full Drug Pay
articles.snippet: Two psychiatrists may have violated rules designed to prevent conflicts of interest in consulting for drug makers.
articles.abstract: Two psychiatrists may have violated rules designed to prevent conflicts of interest in consulting for drug makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A world-renowned Harvard child psychiatrist whose work has helped fuel an explosion in the use of powerful antipsychotic medicines in children earned at least $1.6 million in consulting fees from drug makers from 2000 to 2007 but for years did not report much of this income to university officials, according to information given Congressional investigators.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Benedict Carey

articles.headline: The Long Road to a Clinton Exit
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign was suffused in overconfidence, riven by acrimony and weighted by emotional baggage.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign was suffused in overconfidence, riven by acrimony and weighted by emotional baggage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  By the time the campaign tracked down the small-city Indiana mayor, Bill Clinton was in a lather. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had lost the North Carolina primary that evening and was eager to offset it with a win in Indiana. But a vote-counting delay in one county threatened to rob her of a prime-time victory speech.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: For English Studies, Koreans Say Goodbye to Dad
articles.snippet: Many South Korean children are attending school abroad, accompanied by their mothers but not their fathers.
articles.abstract: Many South Korean children are attending school abroad, accompanied by their mothers but not their fathers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUCKLAND, New Zealand  On a sunny afternoon recently, half a dozen South Korean mothers came to pick up their children at the Remuera Primary School here, greeting one another warmly in a schoolyard filled with New Zealanders.

articles.headline: MGM: A Lion or a Lamb?
articles.snippet: Despite its enduring legacy, the movie studio hasn’t fit the profile of a full-fledged production company in years.
articles.abstract: Despite its enduring legacy, the movie studio hasn’t fit the profile of a full-fledged production company in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: To Create Its Hits, a Company Takes Its Toys on Tour
articles.snippet: Bakugan Battle Brawlers, one of the hottest games in toy stores this year, owes its success to a marketing campaign straight from the Eisenhower era.
articles.abstract: Bakugan Battle Brawlers, one of the hottest games in toy stores this year, owes its success to a marketing campaign straight from the Eisenhower era.
articles.lead_paragraph: The science of toy marketing has come a long way since Wham-O started giving away Hula-Hoops to children on playgrounds in the 1950s. Yet one of the hottest toys in stores this year owes its success to a marketing campaign straight from the Eisenhower era.

articles.headline: Experts See Gains Against Asian Terror Networks
articles.snippet: Policing, improved intelligence and eroded public support have weakened Southeast Asian terrorist networks.
articles.abstract: Policing, improved intelligence and eroded public support have weakened Southeast Asian terrorist networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE  The deadliest terrorist networks in Southeast Asia have suffered significant setbacks in the past three years, weakened by aggressive policing, improved intelligence, enhanced military operations and an erosion of public support, government officials and counterterrorism specialists say.

articles.headline: For Some Music, It Has to Be Wal-Mart and Nowhere Else
articles.snippet: Highlighting the diminishing power of recording labels, Wal-Mart is stepping into the breach and making deals directly with artists.
articles.abstract: Highlighting the diminishing power of recording labels, Wal-Mart is stepping into the breach and making deals directly with artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest music events of the summer has already taken place in Fayetteville, Ark. From Tuesday through Thursday last week, the Bud Walton Arena at the University of Arkansas presented shows by Journey, the country singer Keith Urban, the “American Idol” personality Carrie Underwood and the alternative rock group All-American Rejects.

articles.headline: Uncertainty as Tribune Prepares to Retrench
articles.snippet: To deal with shrinking revenue, Sam Zell, the chairman and chief executive of the Tribune Company, cut staff and is aiming for a 50-50 split between ad and news content.
articles.abstract: To deal with shrinking revenue, Sam Zell, the chairman and chief executive of the Tribune Company, cut staff and is aiming for a 50-50 split between ad and news content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Sam Zell right about the newspaper business?

articles.headline: From a Whistle-Blower to a Target
articles.snippet: Joseph A. Ripp, the man who revealed financial troubles at AOL in 2001, is among several former AOL executives facing a civil lawsuit alleging financial fraud.
articles.abstract: Joseph A. Ripp, the man who revealed financial troubles at AOL in 2001, is among several former AOL executives facing a civil lawsuit alleging financial fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: On May 14, 2001, Joseph A. Ripp, the newly appointed chief financial officer of America Online, faxed a letter to the Las Vegas offices of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen with disturbing news: it appeared that an AOL business partner, and Arthur Andersen client, had forged a signature on a contract and booked several million dollars of sham revenue.

articles.headline: States Take New Tack on Illegal Immigration
articles.snippet: With local demand growing for immigration enforcement, police departments are tackling the issue on their own.
articles.abstract: With local demand growing for immigration enforcement, police departments are tackling the issue on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILTON, Fla.  Three months after the local police inspected more than a dozen businesses searching for illegal immigrants using stolen Social Security numbers, this community in the Florida Panhandle has become more law-abiding, emptier and whiter.

articles.headline: Marijuana Hotbed Retreats on Medicinal Use
articles.snippet: Some residents and officials say California’s medical marijuana law has provided cover for large-scale growers.
articles.abstract: Some residents and officials say California’s medical marijuana law has provided cover for large-scale growers.
articles.lead_paragraph: UKIAH, Calif.  There is probably no marijuana-friendlier place in the country than here in Mendocino County, where plants can grow more than 15 feet high, medical marijuana clubs adopt stretches of highway, and the sticky, sweet aroma of cannabis fills this city’s streets during the autumn harvest.

articles.headline: Rural U.S. Takes Worst Hit as Gas Tops $4 Average
articles.snippet: Across the South, Southwest and the upper Great Plains, low incomes and heavy dependence on trucks are squeezing family budgets.
articles.abstract: Across the South, Southwest and the upper Great Plains, low incomes and heavy dependence on trucks are squeezing family budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: TCHULA, Miss.  Gasoline prices reached a national average of $4 a gallon for the first time over the weekend, adding more strain to motorists across the country.

articles.headline: Golden Age for TV? Yes, on Cable
articles.snippet: Networks have shot by basic cable networks, once the realm of stupid human tricks and commercials for six-minute abs, in the race to the bottom.
articles.abstract: Networks have shot by basic cable networks, once the realm of stupid human tricks and commercials for six-minute abs, in the race to the bottom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s because I’m from Minneapolis, but I’ve always had a soft spot for the Saturday nights on CBS that I spent with Mary Tyler Moore during her show’s heyday in the ’70s. Sure, Saturday night on the Tiffany network also had “All in the Family,” “M*A*S*H” and “The Bob Newhart Show,” but who else could take a nothing day, a Saturday for instance, and suddenly make it all seem worthwhile?

articles.headline: McCain Extends His Outreach, but Evangelicals Are Still Wary
articles.snippet: One of John McCain’s major challenges in the general election will be coaxing a critical voting bloc out of its wait-and-see stance.
articles.abstract: One of John McCain’s major challenges in the general election will be coaxing a critical voting bloc out of its wait-and-see stance.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lori Viars, an evangelical activist in Warren County, Ohio, essentially put her life on hold in the fall of 2004 to run a phone bank for President Bush. Her efforts helped the president’s ambitious push to turn out evangelicals and win that critical swing state in a close election.

articles.headline: Inside Gate, India’s Good Life; Outside, the Servants’ Slums
articles.snippet: Many members of India’s upper middle class have moved to gated communities, with servants who live in nearby slums.
articles.abstract: Many members of India’s upper middle class have moved to gated communities, with servants who live in nearby slums.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India  When the scorch of summer hit this north Indian boomtown, and the municipal water supply worked only a few hours each day, inside a high-rise tower called Hamilton Court, Jaya Chand could turn on her kitchen tap around the clock, and water would gush out.
